name: Kepler-124
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-124 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-124 is a star with 0.5399999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.64 times its radius. It is located 1386.78 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-124 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-124 b

Kepler-124 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.41 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-124.

The mass of Kepler-124 b is 0.45 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-124 b is 0.73 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-124 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-124 c

Kepler-124 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.82 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-124.

The mass of Kepler-124 c is 3.68 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-124 c is 1.75 that of Earth. At 3.68 Earth masses, Kepler-124 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-124 d

Kepler-124 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 30.95 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-124.

The mass of Kepler-124 d is 1.24 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-124 d is 1.11 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-124 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-124, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
